name: TeslaCrypt
notes: Notable for its shutdown in May 2016, when the operators released the master decryption key for free.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; Data Encrypted for Impact
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Targeted files related to video games. Master key was released by authors in May 2016."}
mitigation: Keep browsers and plugins (Flash) patched.

name: SamSam
notes: Continued its targeted attacks, famously hitting the City of Atlanta in March 2018, causing massive disruption.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; Valid Accounts; RDP; Windows Command Shell; Data Encrypted for Impact
impact_metrics: {"estimated_cost_usd":8500000,"notes":"Cost for City of Atlanta. Total ransom paid by victims estimated at $6M+"}

name: SamSam
notes: Highly targeted (not spam-based). Operators would gain access, perform reconnaissance, and then manually deploy the ransomware to critical systems.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; SMB/Windows Admin Shares; Windows Command Shell; Data Encrypted for Impact
impact_metrics: {"estimated_cost_usd":30000000,"notes":"Figure is cumulative impact on victims like City of Atlanta (2018)."}
mitigation: Patch public-facing servers (JBoss, RDP); Strong RDP passwords; Network segmentation.

name: Dharma (Crisis)
notes: Became very prominent in 2018, primarily targeting organizations with weak or exposed RDP.
tactics_techniques: Valid Accounts; RDP; Data Encrypted for Impact
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Often spread via exposed RDP ports. Source code was allegedly leaked, leading to many variants."}
mitigation: Secure RDP; Strong passwords; MFA.

name: Cerber
notes: Remained a major threat in 2017, spread via multiple exploit kits and spam campaigns.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Data Encrypted for Impact
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Continued to be a dominant RaaS platform throughout 2017."}
mitigation: Keep browsers and plugins (Flash) patched; Email filtering.

name: Cerber
notes: One of the most dominant RaaS platforms of 2016-2017.
tactics_techniques: JavaScript/JScript; Data Encrypted for Impact; Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Operated as a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS). Used a text-to-speech component to read the ransom note aloud."}
mitigation: Block malicious attachments; Keep browsers and plugins (Flash) patched; Ad blockers.

name: Locky
notes: After a quiet period, Locky returned with massive spam campaigns in Aug/Sep 2017.
tactics_techniques: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Windows Command Shell; Data Encrypted for Impact
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Resurgence in late 2017 with new variants like 'Lukitus' and 'Ykcol' spread by Necurs."}
mitigation: Email security gateways; Spam filtering; Disable macros.

name: Locky
notes: Initially spread via Word docs with malicious macros, later shifted to .js attachments. Associated with the Dridex botnet operators.
tactics_techniques: Windows Command Shell; Native API; Data Encrypted for Impact; Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
mitigation: Block malicious email attachments (.js, .docm); Disable macros; User training.

name: Dutch police arrest alleged authors of 'CoinVault' ransomware
description: Dutch police arrested two men suspected of developing the CoinVault and Bitcryptor ransomware. Authorities also obtained the decryption key database.
potential_impact_on_malware: Reduces activity of specific ransomware families; provides decryption keys to victims.
notes: Successful law enforcement action that directly led to a decryption tool being made available for victims.

name: Petya
notes: Unlike file-encrypting ransomware, Petya (and its later variant NotPetya) encrypts the file system structure itself.
tactics_techniques: Windows Command Shell; Data Encrypted for Impact; Master Boot Record
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Encrypts the Master File Table (MFT) of the NTFS file system, making the entire disk inaccessible."}
mitigation: Block malicious attachments; User training; MBR protection.

name: Vulnerability in Adobe Flash Player (CVE-2016-1019)
description: A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Adobe Flash Player was disclosed and actively exploited in the wild. Patched by Adobe in APSB16-10.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enables initial access and payload delivery via exploit kits (e.g., Magnitude EK).
notes: Flash vulnerabilities were a primary vector for exploit kits delivering ransomware like Cerber and Locky in 2016.

name: TeslaCrypt operators release master decryption key
description: The operators of the TeslaCrypt ransomware shut down their operation and publicly released the master decryption key, allowing all victims to recover their files for free.
potential_impact_on_malware: Effectively ends the threat from this specific ransomware family.
metrics: {"notes":"All victims can decrypt files for free."}
notes: A rare instance of malware operators voluntarily ending their campaign and helping victims.

name: Temporary shutdown of Necurs botnet
description: The Necurs botnet, the primary distribution engine for Locky ransomware, went offline for several weeks. This caused a massive, immediate drop in Locky spam campaigns.
potential_impact_on_malware: Temporarily halts initial access for a major ransomware family.
notes: Demonstrated the critical dependency of Locky on the Necurs botnet infrastructure.

name: Shadow Brokers first leak
description: The Shadow Brokers group released their first cache of alleged NSA hacking tools. While the most damaging tools (like EternalBlue) were not in this initial dump, it signaled a new threat of nation-state tools being available to criminals.
potential_impact_on_malware: Signaled the future availability of highly effective exploits, which would later be used by ransomware.
notes: This event was the precursor to the 2017 leaks that enabled WannaCry and NotPetya.

name: Krebs on Security hit by record 620 Gbps DDoS
description: Brian Krebs's website was targeted by a massive DDoS attack (620 Gbps) launched by the Mirai botnet, forcing it offline. The scale of the attack was unprecedented at the time.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated the power of IoT botnets and the massive scale of DDoS attacks they could generate.
notes: This event was the first major public demonstration of Mirai's capabilities.

name: Mirai botnet source code released
description: The source code for the Mirai botnet was publicly released on a hacking forum.
potential_impact_on_malware: Dramatically lowers the bar for creating new IoT botnets, leading to numerous variants and widespread scanning/attacks.
notes: Directly led to the proliferation of Mirai variants and the subsequent Dyn DDoS attack.

name: Dirty COW Vulnerability (CVE-2016-5195)
description: A critical privilege escalation vulnerability in the Linux kernel was disclosed. It allowed a local user to gain root privileges.
potential_impact_on_malware: Provides a mechanism for malware on a compromised Linux host (e.g., a web server) to gain full administrative rights.
notes: A fundamental Linux vulnerability that existed for many years, impacting a vast number of servers and devices (including Android).

name: Dyn DNS DDoS Attack
description: The Mirai botnet was used to launch a 1.2 Tbps DDoS attack against DNS provider Dyn, causing widespread outages for major websites in North America and Europe, including Twitter, Netflix, and Reddit.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated the systemic risk of insecure IoT devices to core internet infrastructure.
notes: A landmark event highlighting the real-world impact of IoT botnets.

name: Avalanche botnet infrastructure takedown
description: A global law enforcement operation dismantled the 'Avalanche' botnet infrastructure, which was a delivery platform for numerous malware families, including ransomware and banking trojans.
potential_impact_on_malware: Disrupts the C2 and delivery infrastructure for a wide range of malware families.
notes: A major success in public-private partnership to take down long-lived criminal infrastructure.

name: Spora
notes: Notable for its high-quality code and ability to encrypt files without an internet connection.
tactics_techniques: File and Directory Discovery; Data Encrypted for Impact
technical_traits: {"encryption":"RSA; AES; RC4","features":"Offline encryption (uses embedded public key)"}
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Sophisticated ransomware with a professional-looking payment portal. Capable of offline encryption."}
mitigation: Block malicious .HTA files; User training.

name: Jaff
notes: Another major payload of the Necurs botnet, though it was less successful and shorter-lived than Locky.
tactics_techniques: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Visual Basic; Data Encrypted for Impact
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Distributed heavily by the Necurs botnet in large spam campaigns."}
mitigation: Email security gateways; Spam filtering.

name: WikiLeaks publishes 'Vault 7' (Year Zero)
description: WikiLeaks began publishing 'Vault 7', a series of documents detailing CIA hacking tools and capabilities. This included exploits for iOS, Android, and smart TVs.
potential_impact_on_malware: Revealed numerous zero-day vulnerabilities and nation-state cyber capabilities, increasing awareness and risk.
notes: This leak, along with the Shadow Brokers, highlighted the risk of nation-state tool proliferation.

name: Apache Struts RCE (CVE-2017-5638)
description: A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Apache Struts 2 was disclosed. It was easy to exploit and allowed attackers to take full control of a web server., Apache Struts 2
related_malware_families: Enables initial access to unpatched web servers, leading to data breaches (Equifax) and potential malware deployment.
notes: The vulnerability responsible for the Equifax breach. It was patched, but Equifax failed to apply the patch.

name: Microsoft releases MS17-010
description: Microsoft released security bulletin MS17-010, which patched multiple critical vulnerabilities in the Windows SMBv1 server. This patch was critical in stopping WannaCry, but many organizations failed to apply it.
potential_impact_on_malware: Provides the primary mitigation for the EternalBlue exploit, which fueled the largest ransomware outbreaks of the year.
notes: This was the single most important patch of the year. Failure to apply it led directly to the WannaCry and NotPetya outbreaks.

name: Microsoft Office RCE (CVE-2017-0199)
description: A remote code execution vulnerability in Microsoft Office/WordPad was disclosed. It allowed code execution when a user opened a specially crafted document (e.g., RTF) containing an OLE object., Microsoft Office; WordPad
related_malware_families: Enables initial access via phishing documents. Was used as one of the infection vectors for NotPetya.
notes: This vulnerability was exploited by various malware, including as a secondary vector in the NotPetya attacks.

name: Shadow Brokers leak 'EternalBlue' exploit
description: The Shadow Brokers group leaked the 'EternalBlue' (MS17-010) and 'EternalRomance' exploits, alleged to be NSA tools. These exploits allowed for remote code execution over SMBv1.
potential_impact_on_malware: Dramatically enables wormable malware, allowing ransomware to spread automatically and rapidly across networks without user interaction.
notes: This event provided the weapon (EternalBlue) for the WannaCry and NotPetya attacks just weeks later.

name: WannaCry
notes: Global wormable ransomware outbreak. Spread rapidly by exploiting the 'EternalBlue' SMBv1 vulnerability. Halted by a security researcher activating a 'killswitch' domain.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; SMB/Windows Admin Shares; Exploitation of RemoteServices; Data Encrypted for Impact; Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
persistence_mechanisms: N/A (relied on worm for spread, not strong persistence)
c2_infrastructure: Hard-coded killswitch domain; Hard-coded C2 IPs
mitigation: Apply MS17-010 patch; Disable SMBv1; Block SMBv1 (port 445) at network boundary.

name: WannaCry Outbreak
description: A massive global ransomware attack using the EternalBlue exploit (MS17-010) to spread as a worm. It crippled organizations worldwide, most notably the UK's National Health Service (NHS)., Windows
related_malware_families: Demonstrated the catastrophic impact of combining ransomware with a wormable nation-state exploit.
potential_impact_on_malware: "{""infections"":300000
notes: The first major global wormable ransomware event.

name: NotPetya Outbreak / Wiper Attack
description: A destructive wiper attack disguised as ransomware, primarily targeting Ukraine via a compromised update to M.E.Doc software. It used EternalBlue and other methods for lateral movement, causing over $10B in global damages.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated the use of a supply-chain attack to deploy a wiper with devastating financial and operational impact.
notes: Widely considered the most financially damaging cyberattack in history.

name: AlphaBay and Hansa Market Takedown
description: A coordinated international law enforcement operation seized and shut down two of the largest dark web marketplaces, AlphaBay and Hansa.
potential_impact_on_malware: Disrupts the ecosystem for selling malware, stolen data, and other cybercrime tools.
notes: This operation disrupted a key hub for cybercriminal activity, including RaaS offerings.

name: Equifax Data Breach Announced
description: Equifax announced a massive data breach affecting 147 million people. The breach occurred from May-July 2017 by exploiting a vulnerability in Apache Struts (CVE-2017-5638).
potential_impact_on_malware: Massive loss of sensitive PII (SSNs, birth dates), providing raw material for identity theft and sophisticated phishing for years to come.
notes: One of the most significant PII breaches in history, caused by failure to patch a known vulnerability.

name: Bad Rabbit
notes: A targeted attack primarily hitting Russia and Ukraine, spreading through drive-by downloads on compromised news sites.
tactics_techniques: Phishing: Spearphishing Link; Exploitation of RemoteServices; OS Credential Dumping; Data Encrypted for Impact
propagation_vectors: Drive-by download (fake Flash update); Lateral movement (Mimikatz, hardcoded creds, SMB)
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Contained many components from NotPetya, suggesting a shared developer. Spread via compromised media websites."}
mitigation: User training (fake updates); Patch SMB vulnerabilities; Restrict admin credentials.

name: Huawei Router Vulnerability (CVE-2017-17215)
description: A remote code execution vulnerability in Huawei HG532 routers was disclosed. It was quickly exploited by a variant of the Mirai botnet (Satori)., Huawei HG532
related_malware_families: Provides a new vector for IoT botnets to compromise routers and add them to their network.
notes: Showed the continued evolution of IoT botnets actively incorporating new exploits.

name: Snatch
notes: Snatch operates a ransomware-as-a-service model targeting diverse critical infrastructure; actors brute force RDP and dwell in victims’ networks for months before deploying ransomwarehttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-263a#:~:text=Since%20mid
mitigation: Block RDP access, monitor admin accounts, apply strong passwords and MFA.

name: Snatch
notes: Snatch ransomware-as-a-service continues to target critical infrastructure sectors; actors brute force RDP and run in Windows Safe Mode to evade detectionhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-263a#:~:text=Snatch%20threat%20actors%20employ%20several
mitigation: Block RDP or enforce MFA, monitor for safe mode boot modifications.

name: Meltdown and Spectre Vulnerabilities Disclosed
description: Public disclosure of Meltdown (CVE-2017-5754) and Spectre (CVE-2017-5753, CVE-2017-5715), a class of side-channel vulnerabilities affecting nearly all modern CPUs., Most CPUs (Intel, AMD
potential_impact_on_malware: Fundamental vulnerability in hardware, potentially allowing malware to bypass memory isolation and steal sensitive data (passwords, keys) from other processes.
notes: A landmark event in hardware security, requiring massive patching efforts at the OS and firmware levels.

name: GandCrab
notes: Operated a successful RaaS affiliate program. The developers 'retired' in 2019, claiming to have made over $2B.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment; Exploitation of RemoteServices; Data Encrypted for Impact
propagation_vectors: Phishing (malicious attachments); Exploit Kits (Rig, GrandSoft); RDP brute-force
impact_metrics: {"notes":"One of the most prolific RaaS families of 2018-2019. First major ransomware to demand DASH cryptocurrency."}
mitigation: Patch Office vulnerabilities; Secure RDP; Email filtering.

name: City of Atlanta hit by SamSam Ransomware
description: The City of Atlanta's municipal services were crippled by a targeted SamSam ransomware attack, disrupting services for days and costing millions in recovery., N/A
related_malware_families: Highlighted the vulnerability of municipal governments to targeted ransomware and the high recovery costs.
potential_impact_on_malware: "{""estimated_cost_usd"":8500000
notes: One of the most high-profile ransomware attacks on a US city, demonstrating the impact of 'big game hunting'.

name: Ryuk
notes: Ryuk worked in tandem with TrickBot and Emotet as part of the 2019 triple threat; widely targeted high‑value organisations.
mitigation: Block phishing emails; update antivirus; monitor network for TrickBot/Emotet activity.

name: Ryuk
notes: Emerged in 2018 as a major 'big game hunting' ransomware, deployed manually after network reconnaissance by TrickBot operators.
tactics_techniques: OS Credential Dumping; Process Discovery; File Deletion; RDP; Data Encrypted for Impact
propagation_vectors: Dropped by TrickBot (which was dropped by Emotet); RDP
impact_metrics: {"notes":"'Big game hunting' ransomware. Highly targeted, high-demand ransoms. Part of Emotet->TrickBot->Ryuk chain."}
mitigation: Block Emotet/TrickBot; Secure RDP; Network segmentation; Offline backups.

name: Sodinokibi (REvil)
notes: Although it became most famous in 2019-2021, its origins trace to late 2018 as the GandCrab RaaS was winding down.
tactics_techniques: Exploit Public-Facing Application; Exploitation for Privilege Escalation; Process Discovery; Data Encrypted for Impact
propagation_vectors: Exploitation (Oracle WebLogic); RDP; Dropped by other malware
impact_metrics: {"notes":"Believed to be the successor to GandCrab, operated by the same group. Also a RaaS platform."}
mitigation: Patch WebLogic; Secure RDP; Privilege separation.

name: Snatch
notes: Snatch ransomware observed in 2019 uses a unique technique of rebooting systems into Safe Mode to evade endpoint security.
tactics_techniques: ["Reboots Windows into Safe Mode","Brute force RDP/VNC"]
mitigation: Disable unused remote services; implement strong passwords and lockout policies.

name: Phobos
notes: Phobos ransomware, first identified in 2019, is a variant of the Crysis/Dharma family and spreads via RDP compromise and phishing.
mitigation: Secure RDP endpoints; apply multi-factor authentication; maintain backups.

name: Phobos
notes: The joint advisory on February 29, 2024 highlighted that Phobos ransomware-as-a-service targets municipal governments and public services using phishing and exposed RDP ports, leveraging Smokeloader and Cobalt Strikehttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060a#:~:text=Center%20%28MS,74%202%20%28link%20ishttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060a#:~:text=MITRE%20ATT%26CK%C2%AE%20tactics%20and%20techniques,link%20is%20external.
mitigation: Disable or restrict RDP, use strong passwords, update antivirus and EDR tools.

name: LockerGoga
notes: LockerGoga was first publicly reported in January 2019 after an attack on Altran and later impacted Norsk Hydro and other industrial companies.
mitigation: Monitor for Cobalt Strike/Metasploit activity; restrict admin privileges; implement 2FA.

name: First public report of LockerGoga ransomware
description: Security researchers discovered and publicly reported LockerGoga ransomware after it disrupted French engineering firm Altran. VirusTotal received the earliest sample on this date.
potential_impact_on_malware: Marked the emergence of a dangerous manual ransomware that later impacted other industrial firms.
notes: LockerGoga required manual deployment via compromised credentials.

name: CL0P
notes: Beginning May 27, 2023, the CL0P gang exploited SQL injection vulnerability CVE-2023-34362 in MOVEit Transfer, deploying the LEMURLOOT web shell to steal datahttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-158a#:~:text=According%20to%20open%20source%20information%2C,MFT%20servers%20in%20early%202023.
propagation_vectors: ["Exploitation of MOVEit Transfer", "Exploitation of GoAnywhere MFT"]
mitigation: Apply patches for MOVEit Transfer and other MFT products, limit Internet exposure, monitor for SQL injection.

name: Clop
notes: Clop ransomware first observed in 2019 and is associated with the TA505 cybercrime group. Known for data leak extortion.
mitigation: Block phishing attachments; patch systems; implement data backups.

name: LockerGoga ransomware attack hits Norsk Hydro
description: Norwegian aluminium producer Norsk Hydro suffered a major cyber-attack that forced it to shut down operations across its global organisation. Investigations linked the attack to LockerGoga ransomware.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated destructive potential of manual ransomware in industrial environments.
notes: Hydro publicly communicated the attack and refused to pay ransom.

name: DoppelPaymer
notes: DoppelPaymer ransomware emerged in 2019 and was active in 2020; it used Emotet and Dridex for delivery and launched a data leak site to pressure victims.
tactics_techniques: ["Delivered via Emotet/Dridex","Data leak site","Process termination using Process Hacker"]
mitigation: Train employees on phishing; patch systems; deploy endpoint detection to detect Dridex/Emotet.

name: REvil uses Oracle WebLogic vulnerability (CVE-2019-2725)
description: Attackers began exploiting a deserialization flaw in Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2019-2725) to deploy the new ransomware Sodinokibi/REvil. Oracle released a patch on April 26.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enabled initial access for REvil campaigns and signaled rise of aggressive RaaS.
notes: The vulnerability allowed unauthenticated remote code execution in WebLogic.

name: REvil (Sodinokibi)
notes: Sodinokibi/REvil first exploited Oracle WebLogic vulnerability CVE-2019-2725 in April 2019; later adopted RaaS model and double extortion.
mitigation: Patch Oracle WebLogic; restrict internet-exposed services; implement email filtering and network segmentation.

name: Maze
notes: Maze introduced double extortion in late 2019; first appeared May 2019 and exploited Citrix and Pulse Secure vulnerabilities.
tactics_techniques: ["Phishing emails","Exploiting Citrix ADC and Pulse Secure VPN"]
mitigation: Apply patches for known vulnerabilities (Citrix CVE-2019-19781 and Pulse Secure CVE-2019-11510), enforce MFA, implement network segmentation.

name: Microsoft releases fix for BlueKeep (CVE-2019-0708)
description: Microsoft issued a critical patch for the remote desktop vulnerability known as BlueKeep. The wormable bug (CVE-2019-0708) could allow remote code execution on unpatched Windows systems.
potential_impact_on_malware: Unpatched systems provided potential entry points for ransomware operators until widely patched.
notes: BlueKeep exploitation was later observed in the wild in November 2019.

name: Maze pioneers double extortion with public leak site
description: Maze operationalizes data-leak sites and the double-extortion model, increasing leverage against victims.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enables post-encryption pressure via public data leaks; drives higher payouts
notes: 2019-2020 campaigns popularized data-leak extortion

name: NetWalker
notes: NetWalker (Mailto) ransomware was first detected in August 2019; it introduced a RaaS program in March 2020 and used vulnerabilities in VPN and web servers to gain access.
tactics_techniques: ["Exploiting VPN and RDP vulnerabilities","COVID‑19 themed phishing","Double extortion"]
mitigation: Patch VPN and server software; disable exposed RDP; educate employees on phishing.

name: Texas local government ransomware attack
description: A coordinated ransomware attack affected more than 20 small local government entities in Texas. The state activated its operations center and by August 23 had moved victims into recovery; no ransom was paid.
potential_impact_on_malware: Highlighted vulnerabilities in municipal networks and spurred guidance on incident response and recovery.
notes: The incident underscored the importance of preparedness in smaller government agencies.

name: Emotet botnet reactivates after three‑month hiatus
description: Check Point researchers observed the Emotet botnet resume activity in August 2019 after being dormant since June. The botnet renewed spam campaigns with malicious Word documents delivering Emotet.
potential_impact_on_malware: Reactivation boosted distribution of TrickBot and Ryuk, fueling subsequent ransomware incidents.
notes: Emotet returned as the fifth most prevalent malware in September 2019.

name: LockBit
notes: Operation Cronos in February 2024 seized LockBit’s infrastructure, compromised 34 servers, arrested two operators, and froze millions in cryptocurrency; LockBit had attacked over 2,500 victims across 120 countrieshttps://www.europol.europa.eu/media-press/newsroom/news/law-enforcement-disrupt-worlds-biggest-ransomware-operation#:~:text=This%20international%20sweep%20follows%20a,level%20by%20Europol%20and%20Eurojusthttps://www.justice.gov/archives/opa/pr/us-charges-russian-national-developing-and-operating-lockbit-ransomware#:~:text=The%20U,ransomware%20group%20in%20the%20world.
mitigation: Implement multi-factor authentication, patch Citrix and ScreenConnect vulnerabilities, monitor for suspicious lateral movement.

name: LockBit
notes: LockBit 3.0 affiliates exploited Citrix Bleed vulnerability CVE-2023-4966 from August 2023 to steal session cookies and bypass multifactor authenticationhttps://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa23-325a#:~:text=CVE
mitigation: Update Citrix NetScaler ADC/Gateway to patched versions, invalidate active sessions, enforce MFA.

name: Mirai variants drive large-scale IoT DDoS
description: Proliferation of Mirai strains leveraging insecure ARM IoT devices for DDoS and proxy resale.
potential_impact_on_malware: Enables massive DDoS capacity and commoditized proxy networks
notes: Variant activity ongoing through 2019; scale depends on ISP filtering and device hygiene

name: Snatch ransomware observed rebooting Windows into Safe Mode
description: Sophos researchers discovered Snatch ransomware employing a novel technique: it forces Windows into Safe Mode to bypass security software before encrypting files.
potential_impact_on_malware: Illustrated evolving ransomware evasion tactics, prompting vendors to update detection strategies.
notes: The safe mode technique prevented many endpoint products from loading.

name: BlueKeep exploitation detected in the wild
description: By November 2019 security researchers observed active exploitation of the BlueKeep RDP vulnerability (CVE‑2019‑0708). Wormable exploits targeted unpatched systems despite Microsoft’s earlier patch release.
potential_impact_on_malware: Raised concerns about ransomware worms similar to WannaCry and prompted urgency to patch.
notes: Although exploitation was limited, it demonstrated real-world risk for unpatched systems.

name: Ragnar Locker
notes: Ragnar Locker attacks were discovered by the FBI in April 2020; it had been active since December 2019 and used a VirtualBox VM to evade detection.
tactics_techniques: ["Brute-force RDP","Privilege escalation via CVE-2017-0213","VirtualBox VM to evade detection"]
mitigation: Disable RDP or enforce MFA; apply security updates; monitor for unusual VM installations.

name: Conti
notes: Conti ransomware operation shut down on May 19, 2022 after splitting into smaller groups following internal leaks and geopolitical backlashhttps://thehackernews.com/2022/05/conti-ransomware-gang-shut-down-after.html#:~:text=%EE%A0%82May%2024%2C%202022%EE%A0%84Ravie%20Lakshmanan.
mitigation: Disable RDP, update Microsoft Exchange, implement segmentation.

name: Maze ransomware pioneers double extortion
description: Late in 2019, the Maze ransomware group began threatening to publish stolen data unless victims paid ransom, initiating the double‑extortion model that later became common among ransomware actors.
potential_impact_on_malware: Introduced a new extortion tactic that increased leverage on victims and inspired other groups (e.g., REvil, Conti).
notes: The double‑extortion model involved stealing data before encryption and threatening publication.

name: 2019 sees the “triple threat” of Emotet, TrickBot and Ryuk
description: Year‑end reports highlighted that the combination of Emotet as an initial loader, TrickBot for lateral movement, and Ryuk ransomware caused significant harm to organisations in 2019. The synergy allowed attackers to gain persistence, spread across networks and deploy destructive encryption.
potential_impact_on_malware: Demonstrated how modular malware ecosystems amplify impact; influenced future RaaS collaborations.
notes: The triple threat remained a dominant ransomware delivery chain into 2020.

name: Conti
notes: Conti ransomware was first observed at the end of 2019 and became prominent in 2020; it uses TrickBot for initial access and applies double extortion.
mitigation: Disable SMBv1; patch systems; monitor for TrickBot infections; implement network segmentation.

name: Pysa (Mespinoza)
notes: Pysa (Mespinoza) ransomware emerged in early 2020 and targeted government and healthcare organisations using manual deployment and double extortion.
mitigation: Secure RDP access; implement endpoint monitoring; maintain offsite backups.

name: NetWalker ransomware operators launch affiliate program
description: In March 2020, the NetWalker gang introduced a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) affiliate model, allowing other attackers to deploy its malware in exchange for a revenue share.
potential_impact_on_malware: Expanded reach of NetWalker attacks through affiliate-driven distribution.
notes: The RaaS program attracted affiliates and increased attack volume.

name: Ryuk/Conti affiliates target high-value enterprises
description: Affiliate-driven operations expand, focusing on enterprise ransomware with multi-million USD demands.
potential_impact_on_malware: Accelerates ransomware scale via professionalized affiliate model
notes: Conti emerging from Ryuk; campaigns intensified during 2020

name: FBI identifies Ragnar Locker ransomware active since December 2019
description: Authorities discovered that the Ragnar Locker group had been attacking organisations since December 2019. The group used RDP brute‑force and the Windows COM vulnerability CVE‑2017‑0213 for privilege escalation.
potential_impact_on_malware: Showcased new techniques such as executing ransomware inside a VirtualBox VM to evade detection.
notes: The discovery emphasised the need for strong RDP security and VM monitoring.

name: TrickBot/QakBot loader infrastructure fuels ransomware
description: Persistent loader and malspam infrastructure provides initial access, credential theft, and staging for ransomware.
potential_impact_on_malware: Sustains large-scale initial access and lateral movement for ransomware operations
notes: Acted as a feeder for multiple ransomware families across 2020

name: Avaddon
notes: Avaddon ransomware was first seen in June 2020 and uses phishing emails containing a double‑extension JavaScript file; affiliates use BITS and PowerShell to download payloads.
tactics_techniques: ["Phishing emails with double-extension JS downloader","Abuse of BITS and PowerShell","Double extortion"]
mitigation: Educate users about phishing; disable unsolicited JS execution; monitor BITS usage.

name: Avaddon ransomware discovered
